heading.title: PART 2 THE LOCAL COURT OF NEW SOUTH WALES [ss 7–28]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 2 THE LOCAL COURT OF NEW SOUTH WALES [ss 7–28]
[LCA07 s 22] s 22 Sittings of the Court (cf LCA 1982, section 11)

leg:heading.title: Sittings of the Court (cf LCA 1982, section 11 )

p.text: Sittings of the Court are to be held at such places and times as the Chief Magistrate may from time to time direct by notice published in the Gazette.
More than one sitting of the Court may be held at the same time.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 23] s 23 Arrangement of business of the Court (cf LCA 1982, sections 11 and 14)

p.text: The Chief Magistrate is responsible for ensuring the orderly and expeditious discharge of the business of the Court and for that purpose may, subject to this Act, give directions as to:
the Magistrates or Assessors who are to exercise the Court’s jurisdiction in specified matters or matters of a specified class, and
the Magistrates or Assessors who are to sit at places (including one or more designated places) in the State or exercise certain functions at those places, and
the matters or classes of matters that may be dealt with at those places, and
the specified functions that are to be exercised by specified Magistrates or Magistrates of a specified class.
[subs (1) am Act 37 of 2009 Sch 1.8[6], [7], effective 19 June 2009]

The Chief Magistrate must consult with the Attorney General before making a direction under subsection (1) that substantially alters the frequency of sittings at a particular place relative to the previous calendar year.
The Chief Magistrate may have such consultation with other Magistrates as is appropriate and practicable before making any direction under subsection (1) .
A direction given under subsection (1) may provide for:
the establishment of circuits comprised of places at which sittings of the Court are required to be held, or
the exercise by Magistrates of their functions, at specified times or during specified periods, at different places.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 24] s 24 Contempt of court (cf LCA 1982, sections 27A and 27B)

p.text: The Court has, if it is alleged, or appears to the Court on its own view, that a person is guilty of contempt of court committed in the face of the Court or in the hearing of the Court, the same powers as the District Court has in those circumstances.
Without limiting subsection (1) , the Court may vacate or revoke an order with respect to contempt of court.
For the purposes of this section:
sections 199 , 200 and 202 of the District Court Act 1973 apply to the Local Court and a Magistrate in the same way as they apply to the District Court and a Judge of the District Court, and
a reference in section 200 of that Act to a proclaimed place is taken to be a reference to a designated place, and
section 201 of that Act applies to a ruling, order, direction or decision of the Local Court under those provisions as so applied.

Without prejudice to the powers of the Court under this section, if it is alleged, or appears to the Court on its own view, that a person is guilty of contempt of the Court, whether committed in the face or hearing of the Court or not, the Court may refer the matter to the Supreme Court for determination.
The Supreme Court is to dispose of any matter referred to it under this section in the manner it considers appropriate.

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 24.5] Contempt — the concept and its purpose

heading.title: Contempt — the concept and its purpose

p.text: “Contempt in the face of the court involves manifold aspects … its essence is conduct, active or inactive, amounting to an interference with or obstruction to, or a tendency to interfere with or obstruct, the due administration of justice, using that term in a broad sense”: Ex parte Dunn (1906) 12 ALR 358 at 360 per Cussen J; Ex parte Bellanto; Re Prior [1963] NSWR 1556; [1963] SR (NSW) 190 at 202 ; Parashuram Deteram Shamdasani v King-Emperor [1945] AC 264 at 268; (1945) 61 TLR 448 ; Ex parte Tuckerman; Re Nash [1970] 3 NSWR 23 . “It is not possible to particularise the acts which can or cannot constitute contempt in the face of the court”: Izuora v R [1953] AC 327 at 336 per Lord Tucker. The power to punish for contempt is not for the purpose of vindicating the personal dignity of the judges and protecting them from personal insults as individuals. The vindication of the dignity of the judge is of subordinate importance to the dignity of the court itself: R v Castro (Skipworth's case) (1873) LR9QB 219 at 232 per Blackburn J, cited with approval in Ex parte Bellanto; Re Prior [1963] NSWR 1556; [1963] SR (NSW) 190 at 199–200 ; see also Ex parte Fernandez (1861) 30 LJCP 321 at 332 per Earl CJ. “In dealing with cases of contempt judges are required to separate themselves personally from the position which they hold.” Lord Denning MR said in R v Metropolitan Police Cmr; Ex parte Blackburn (No 2) [1968] 2 QB 150 at 155; [1968] 2 All ER 319 . “Let me say at once that we will never use this jurisdiction as a means to uphold our own dignity. That must rest on surer foundations. Nor will we use it to suppress those who speak against us. We do not fear criticism, nor do we resent it’ ”: Ellenbogen v Cullen [1990] Petty SR 4065.

The summary power of punishing for contempt should be used sparingly and only in serious cases. "Courts should not be oversensitive or make mountains out of mole hills in exercising the power to punish for contempt. Some matters are unworthy of answer or comment or even notice": Ellenbogen v Cullen [1990] Petty SR 4065 at 4067, citing Parashuram Detaram Shamdasani v King-Emperor [1945] AC 264 at 268 . “It is a power which a court must of necessity possess; its usefulness depends on the wisdom and restraint with which it is exercised”: Izuora v R [1953] AC 327 at 336 ; Parashuram , above at 270; Ellenbogen , above at 4067. "The power is to be used where it can be said that the conduct — active or inactive is preventing or obstructing or tending to prevent or obstruct a trial from proceeding in the ordinary course of justice, fairly and impartially": Ellenbogen , above, at 4067.

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 24.10] In the face or hearing of the court

heading.title: In the face or hearing of the court

p.text: The meaning of the phrase “in the face of the court” is ambiguous and uncertain. On the one hand, it has been interpreted as relating solely to those matters which are within the personal knowledge of the court, so that the presiding judicial officer can then deal summarily with the matter “without the embarrassment of having to be a witness to issues of fact which may be in dispute because of events occurring outside”: Laskin J in McKeown v R (1971) 16 DLR (3d) 390 at 408 cited by Kirby P in European Asian Bank AG v Wentworth (1986) 5 NSWLR 445 . On the other hand, it has been said that the concept extends to conduct wider than that which a judge may see with his or her own eyes and that it covers all contempts for which a judge of his or her own motion could punish a person on the spot: Balogh v St Albans Crown Court [1975] QB 73 at 84; [1974] 3 All ER 283 per Denning LJ. A view between these two extremes was accepted in Registrar, Court of Appeal v Collins [1982] 1 NSWLR 682 where contempt in the face of the court was said to extend to conduct occurring outside the actual court room which is sufficiently proximate in time and space to the trial of the proceedings then in progress or imminent so as to present confrontation to the trial: compare Ex parte Tubman; Re Lucas (1970) 92 WN (NSW) 320. This proposition was doubted by Kirby P and McHugh JA in Fraser v R [1984] 3 NSWLR 212; (1984) 15 A Crim R 58 .

In European Asian Bank AG v Wentworth (1986) 5 NSWLR 445 , Priestley JA said that the point was not settled and that it would be difficult to criticise a judicial officer at first instance for adopting either view. In the same case, Kirby P said that there were reasons of policy for confining the summary procedures to cases actually seen, heard or otherwise sensed by the court itself. It is submitted that this narrow construction is to be preferred so that the court is saved the embarrassment of determining disputed issues of fact relating to events which have occurred outside the courtroom by the summary mode of procedure applicable to contempt proceedings and secondly because of the inherent difficulty of defining the geographical boundaries outside the courtroom for the purpose of the exercise of the court's jurisdiction: see McKeown v R (1971) 16 DLR (3d) 390 and European Asian Bank AG v Wentworth, above. In R v Sleiman (No 29) [1999] NSWSC 858; BC9905398 , Sperling J utilised the summary procedure to punish for contempt without procedural formality in a case where the contempt, in the form of a threat to the witness, whilst committed in the courtroom had not been observed by the trial judge.

The procedure set out in District Court Act 1973 s 199(3) , now applicable in the Local Court by virtue of LCA 2007 s 24(3) is that:
the contemnor is to be informed orally of the contempt with which he or she is charged;
the contemnor is required to make his or her defence to the charge;
after hearing the contemnor, the court determines the matter of the charge;
the court then makes an order for the punishment or discharge of the contemnor.

It is in the discretion of the court whether to grant an adjournment for the alleged contemnor to obtain legal representation or otherwise. In this regard, the court must balance questions of natural justice and fairness to the defendant in the context of what may be perceived to be an interference with or obstruction to the due administration of justice and the necessity to take prompt and appropriate action in relation thereto: Morris v Crown Office [1970] 2 QB 114; [1970] 1 All ER 1079 ; Ex parte Tuckerman; Re Nash [1970] 3 NSWR 23 .

The court should defer forming any concluded opinion as to the inference to be drawn from the defendant's words or conduct until there is placed in the scale everything that the defendant might fairly wish to say, not only upon the question as to whether his or her purported answers amounted to a contempt of the court, but, if so, what the sentence of the court should be: Coward v Stapleton (1953) 90 CLR 573 at 581; [1953] ALR 743; BC5301000 . In this regard, the defendant will generally make an oral statement to the court, a statement which may be made on oath if he or she so elects: Fraser v R [1984] 3 NSWLR 212; (1984) 15 A Crim R 58 .

Contempt in the face of the court is criminal in nature and the ingredients of the charge must be proved beyond reasonable doubt: Witham v Holloway (1995) 183 CLR 525; 131 ALR 401; [1995] HCA 3; BC9506443 . Proof of an intention to interfere in the administration of justice is not an ingredient of the charge: Attorney-General (NSW) v Dean (1990) 20 NSWLR 650; 50 A Crim R 342 . If the court is satisfied with the explanation given or that the accused has sufficiently purged his or her contempt, he or she is discharged. If not, the court may proceed to punish. If the accused has not made submissions on the question of punishment in his earlier statement, he or she should be given the opportunity to do so: Prothonotary v Wilson [1999] NSWSC 1148; BC9907753 .

As to the above procedures, see generally Ex parte Bellanto; Re Prior [1963] NSWR 1556; [1963] SR (NSW) 190 and Ex parte Tuckerman; Re Nash, above; Fraser v R, above; Toner v A-G (NSW) (NSWCA, Kirby P, Clarke JA and Hope AJA, No 40101/91, 19 November 1991, unreported, BC9101415).

If the alleged contemnor is indigent and unable to obtain legal representation through no fault of his or her own, it would seem that the proceedings should be stayed. The contemnor must present an arguable case that he or she has been denied legal representation through no fault of his or her own: see Re Ellis; Ex parte Torney (2000) 74 ALJR 693 , where it was held that the alleged contemnor failed to discharge this onus, and that in any event he should have availed himself of his appeal rights to the Full Court of the Family Court.

In the context of contempt constituting conduct active or inactive, amounting to an interference with or obstruction to, or having a tendency to interfere with or obstruct, the due administration of justice, the following have been held to constitute contempt in the face of the court:

repeated gestures by a number of defendants in raising their arms with fists clenched towards the magistrate, such gestures being associated with principles and attitudes constituting a denial of the rule of law: Ex parte Tuckerman; Re Nash [1970] 3 NSWR 23 ;

words uttered by counsel to the trial judge in defiance of the trial judge's ruling, such words being perceived by the trial judge as a tactic or manoeuvre to obtain a discharge of the jury: Ex parte Bellanto; Re Prior [1963] NSWR 1556; [1963] SR (NSW) 190 ;

threats to a witness: European Asian Bank AG v Wentworth (1986) 5 NSWLR 445 at 450 per Kirby P; Moore v Clerk of Assize, Bristol [1971] 1 WLR 1669 at 1670 per Denning MR; R v Sleiman (No 29) [1999] NSWSC 858; BC9905398 .

In Prothonotary v Wilson [1999] NSWSC 1148; BC9907753 , it was held that throwing plastic bags of paint at a judge, drawn from a secret cavity in a folder, was premeditated intentional contempt. It was deemed behaviour that was likely to interfere with the administration of justice and undermine the authority of the courts, for which the defendant was sentenced to a fixed term of 2 years' imprisonment. In view of subjective factors this was reduced on appeal to time served (3 months and 20 days): Wilson v Prothonotary [2000] NSWCA 23; BC200000520 .
The following have been held not to constitute contempt:

calling the court a “kangaroo court” in circumstances where the judge sitting on appeal from the magistrate's decision considered the words complained of to be part of a genuine forensic endeavour on the part of the defendant to argue his or her case: Sellers v Price (NSWSC, Carruthers J, 23 May 1986, unreported);
refusing to remove a head band with political overtones after being requested to do so by the presiding magistrate: Ellenbogen v Cullen [1990] Petty SR 4065;
counsel absenting himself from a part-heard divorce case without leave and against the direction of the presiding judge: Izuora v R [1953] AC 327 ;

solicitor for the party remaining silent in court when subpoena to produce documents called upon, no documents being produced in circumstances where the solicitor was aware of the existence of certain documents which fell within the terms of the subpoena: Ditfort v Brown (1990) 19 NSWLR 49 . It was held (at 53F) that any contempt of the kind alleged required positive conduct by some person directly involved in the relevant processes of the court including a refusal to answer questions, which was lacking;

discourtesy such as a barrister shouting at a judge after a dispute about whether the barrister had objected to the tender of certain documents: Toner v A-G (NSW) (NSWCA, Kirby P, Clarke JA and Hope AJA, No 40101/91, 19 November 1991, unreported, BC9101415), applying Lewis v Ogden (1984) 153 CLR 682; 53 ALR 53; BC8400532 .

failing to attend court as a witness on a day upon which the witness was not informed that he had to attend (being a day after that specified in the subpoena): Gibbons v R (VCA, Brooking, Hayne, Charles JJA, 5602/96, 30 June 1997, unreported, BC9703281).
As to the court's powers to order the removal from the court of a counsel who misbehaves and thereafter refuse to hear him or her in the same proceedings, see Bell v Norton [1983] ACLD 614.

Under CPA s 53 , a person may not wilfully insult an arbitrator or other person, wilfully misbehave during or interrupt the hearing of referred proceedings, assault or wilfully obstruct an arbitrator or other person or, without lawful excuse, disobey a lawful direction given to him or her by an arbitrator during the hearing of referred proceedings. The arbitrator may direct a person who contravenes those requirements to leave the sitting of the arbitrator, and the person to whom the direction is given must immediately comply with the direction, in default of which he or she is punishable for contempt.
Legislation cited in [LCA07 s 24.35] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 s 199(7).
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 75A(3).
(NSW) Crimes (Sentencing Procedure) Act 1999 s 17.

The maximum penalty provided by District Court Act 1973 s 199(7) , made applicable by SCA s 75A(3) is a fine of 20 penalty units ($2200 as at March 2005) or 28 days' imprisonment. The value of a penalty unit is set out in s 17 of the Crimes (Sentencing Procedure) Act 1999 and is $110 (as at 16 November 2007). Alternatives to imprisonment such as home detention, periodic detention or a community service order may be available if the defendant is assessed as suitable by the Probation and Parole Service. In Cook v Phillips (NSWCA, Kirby ACJ, Mahoney AP and Sheller JA, No 40269/95, 29 September 1995, unreported, BC9505437), a case involving threats to a witness in the court room not seen or heard by the trial judge, the Court of Appeal deemed it sufficient penalty to make a declaration that the conduct of the contemnor amounted to contempt which had been proved beyond reasonable doubt, and to order the contemnor to pay the complainant's costs on an indemnity basis (applying McIntyre v Perkes (1988) 15 NSWLR 417; BC8801160 ).

p.text: Legislation cited in [LCA07 s 24.40] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Local Court Act 2007 s 24(4), 24(5).
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 s 199(7), s 203.

heading.title: LCA 2007 s 24(4), 24(5) — Power to refer 'the matter' to the Supreme Court

p.text: Notwithstanding the fact that the Local Court has jurisdiction under the section, it may still refer the allegation of contempt to the Supreme Court under LCA 2007 s 24(4) and 24(5) in appropriate circumstances, for example, if the penalty provided for under s 199(7) of the District Court Act 1973, is considered insufficient. The section reflects District Court Act 1973 s 203 , added to that Act by the District Court (Procedure) Amendment Act 1984 No 170. The genesis of the section may be found in Attorney-General (NSW) v Davis (NSWCA, Moffit P, Hope and Hutley JJA, 23 July 1980, unreported), a case where two persons threatened the victim in a homosexual rape case while he was waiting to give evidence in a corridor adjacent to the court room where the trial was proceeding. In the following extract, references to "District Court" and "judge" may be construed in the present context to read "Local Court" and "magistrate" respectively:

There will at times be important reasons why a District Court judge may not wish to embark upon proceedings for contempt in respect of an occurrence which has some relation to a trial in progress or about to commence before him. In such a case it may appear to the District Court judge that it is necessary or important that some proceedings for contempt be initiated. The above situation may arise where the alleged contempt is not committed in the face of the court as defined by the relevant authorities, or where there is some doubt whether it is. In the one case the judge will have no power to punish for the contempt and in the other he may consider it preferable not to assume jurisdiction which is open to doubt when it could be dealt with by the Supreme Court exercising jurisdiction not open to doubt. Further, even in cases where there is no uncertainty concerning jurisdiction a District Court judge may well (as may any first instance judge) very properly take the view that it is preferable that the trial of an issue of contempt and its punishment, be tried other than by himself, because of his closeness to the events constituting the alleged contempt. If an incident prima facie constituting contempt has or may appear to have some relationship with the conduct of the judge himself, (a circumstance not present in the subject case), the role of the accuser and judge may conflict or appear to do so. There is much to commend the view that in many of such cases where it can be conveniently done, it is preferable that the charge of contempt be dealt with by another judge or court, particularly where the authority of the court to prevent interference with the continuation of the trial does not require that the trial be interrupted in order to deal with the charge of contempt. In many cases the authority of the judge will be established by the person being charged and powers of detention exercised pending their determination. The desirability of a judge leaving the trial of a charge of contempt to another judge or court in an appropriate case has often been adverted to; and indeed appellate experience has shown that the exercise of jurisdiction, in respect of conduct seen to interfere with the authority of the judge, is in those cases most often found to be productive of error of some kind. In such cases the line between an affront to the judge and conduct tending to interfere with the administration of justice is prone to be blurred. To enable a judge to intervene and cause a person to be charged and make any other provision such as arrest or detention in the meantime and not then try the charge himself, it is important that there be some single continuous procedures enabling this to be achieved. Nothing here said is intended to suggest that in the great majority of cases circumstances will require that the judge intervene and deal with the matter; perhaps swiftly and severely in order to establish the authority of the court in the proceedings in the interests of the due administration of justice.

The Court of Appeal thus emphasised the desirability of there being appropriate machinery to enable a judge of the District Court, and judicial officers of "other courts having a limited power to deal with contempt", to refer to the Supreme Court a charge of contempt. The Supreme Court exercises a general supervisory jurisdiction over inferior courts, including the power to punish for contempt: Attorney-General (NSW) v Mirror Newspapers Ltd [1980] 1 NSWLR 374 and the cases cited there. District Court Act 1973 s 203 and the present section have now rectified that deficiency.

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 24.45] The Local Court's powers under the section

p.text: Legislation cited in [LCA07 s 24.45] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Local Court Act 2007 s 24(1)–(3), s 24(4).

heading.title: The Local Court's powers under the section

p.text: The powers conferred by s 24(4) are in addition to those under s 24(1)–(3) , which are limited to contempts in the face or hearing of the court. The jurisdiction under s 24(4) may be invoked where it is inappropriate to deal with the matter under s 24(1)–(3) , either because there is no jurisdiction under that section, or where it is otherwise inappropriate to deal with the matter under those subsections as, for example, where the penalty therefore provided is inadequate: Registrar, Court of Appeal v Maniam (No 1) (1991) 25 NSWLR 459 at 464G, 469G . Firstly, for the power under subs (4) to be exercised it must be alleged or appear to the court that a person is guilty of contempt of court. Procedurally, this may be done by detailing the facts to the alleged contemnor and asking whether he or she agrees with them. Secondly, the judge (or magistrate) must ordinarily afford to the person the opportunity of showing why, in the exercise of s 24(4) , he or she should not refer the matter to the Supreme Court for determination. There is no precise procedure stipulated for this. If the alleged contemnor desires to show reasons why the power should not be exercised, it is not inappropriate that he or she should be given the opportunity to do so by sworn evidence. It may be that, strictly, sworn evidence is the only or ordinary method of doing so. Thirdly, the judge (or magistrate) may, in the exercise of the discretion conferred by the section, then refer the matter to the Supreme Court for determination. It is not clear whether a formal charge of contempt is necessary. It is arguable that a formal charge is not warranted or authorised. That which the section authorises to be referred to the Supreme Court is "the matter". "The term 'matter' in this sense ordinarily indicates a proceeding between parties oralis: at least it may do so. And, I think, until there is a charge in respect of the apparent contempt, it may be that there is no 'matter' which may be referred": Maniam (No 1) , above at 470E–471B per Mahoney JA where, however, the failure to prefer a formal charge was not held to affect the validity or the propriety of the proceedings before the Court of Appeal.

heading.title: Procedure once the matter is referred to the Supreme Court

p.text: Once the matter is referred to the Supreme Court, “the registrar must commence proceedings for punishment of the contempt, and no direction from the Court shall be necessary to enable the registrar to do so”: SCR Pt 55 r 11(3) .
Legislation cited in [LCA07 s 24.55] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Crimes (Sentencing Procedure) Act 1999.

Where the matter is referred to the Supreme Court, there are no prescribed limits on the power to imprison or fine: Registrar, Court of Appeal v Maniam (No 2) (1992) 26 NSWLR 309 at 314 , where the relevant criteria to be considered are set out. The Crimes (Sentencing Procedure) Act 1999 applies to sentencing for contempt: Principal Registrar of the Supreme Court of NSW v Jando (2001) 53 NSWLR 527; [2001] NSWSC 969; BC200106715 , where consideration was given to applicable sentencing principles for contempt in the form of refusal by a Crown witness to answer questions at a criminal trial in the District Court.
